text.p: Given the picture above in [mathjaxinline]\mathbb R^2[/mathjaxinline], can you write [mathjaxinline]w[/mathjaxinline] as a linear combination [mathjaxinline]w = a_1 v_1 + a_2 v_2[/mathjaxinline]? If so, enter possible values for [mathjaxinline]a_1[/mathjaxinline] and [mathjaxinline]a_2[/mathjaxinline]. If not, enter No in both boxes.

font.p: Notice how the grid of parallelograms shows us where we can expect to end up by applying [mathjaxinline]v_1[/mathjaxinline] and [mathjaxinline]v_2[/mathjaxinline] by various amounts; each lattice point is a linear combination, with integer coefficients, of [mathjaxinline]v_1[/mathjaxinline] and [mathjaxinline]v_2[/mathjaxinline]. The question is, what combination of [mathjaxinline]v_1[/mathjaxinline] and [mathjaxinline]v_2[/mathjaxinline] gives us the same net effect as [mathjaxinline]w[/mathjaxinline]? Since the head of [mathjaxinline]w[/mathjaxinline] lies on a lattice point of the grid, we can simply count our way to the answer: a movement of -1 spaces in the [mathjaxinline]v_1[/mathjaxinline] direction, and a movement of 2 spaces in the [mathjaxinline]v_2[/mathjaxinline] direction, takes us from the tail to the head of [mathjaxinline]w[/mathjaxinline].
